author: Nick Dent
title: Crimson Peak: Guillermo del Toro’s gothic horror reviewed
text:
“GHOSTS are real,” we are told by Edith Cushing (Mia Wasikowska), a late-19th century American heiress, at the start of Crimson Peak, and we don’t have to wait long for the proof.
There are spooks in this film: grotesque, horrifying, in-your-face ones. Guillermo Del Toro is not the kind of horror filmmaker to leave monsters unseen behind creaky doors for any length of time.
His heroine here is an aspiring young authoress with a taste for the supernatural: she prefers Mary Shelley to Jane Austen. She also prefers literature to men. That is until the dashing Baronet Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston) sweeps into her life, seeking her father’s investment in a mining scheme, and soon, Edith’s hand.
Readers of Victorian literature won’t be surprised when Edith finds herself installed at the Baronet’s gloomy, windswept castle in the north of England, not far, geographically or thematically, from Wuthering Heights.
Tom Hiddleston, left, and Mia Wasikowska in a scene from Crimson Peak. Dead leaves fall into this stately home through a crumbling ceiling. Rotting insects crowd the side tables and livid red clay oozes up from the earth like congealing blood.
There’s no mad woman in the attic, but there are more
g-g-g-ghosts than a Scooby Doo box set.

His new film mines Victorian novels of sensation and suspense, with liberal doses of the Bronte sisters and Daphne du Maurier.
Mia Wasikowska in a scene from Crimson Peak. Jessica Chastain cuts a fine, icy figure as Thomas’s spinster sister, a Mrs Danvers type who expresses her loathing for her brother’s new wife by offering her endless cups of tea.
Charlie Hunnam, who starred in Del Toro’s Pacific Rim, plays an ophthalmologist who fancies himself a bit of a Sherlock Holmes.
But perhaps the true star is the costuming by Kate Hawley, which is gorgeous: a florid expression of all the passions and terrors playing out here.
This is not a subtle film. It’s not even unpredictable. But it is an awful lot of ghoulish, melodramatic fun.

CRIMSON PEAK
Released by Universal
Star rating 4/5
Director Guillermo del Toro
Starring Mia Wasikowska, Tom Hiddleston, Jessica Chastain
